annotation.TEXT: If you've read the description already, you'd know that I initially wasn't going to get the Shoryuken in this playthrough. Since I've opted to do so now however, this is the one part of the run where I actually need to be careful (instead of employing the usual, reckless strategy of "bump into everything ever").

No strange message accompanied by a random sound-bite this time, sadly (again, this was mostly due to issues with my video editing and recording software). The next game I plan on doing will have it, though.

When you fall into the hole, keeping Zero's text box on-screen will allow you to perform the second part of this glitch. Wait for Sigma's text box to override Zero's, and you'll find that you can actually move around as his pre-fight animation is playing. If you perform a Shoryuken before this finishes, you'll be completely invincible...for the first phase, at least. You'll also lose the invincibility if you perform the input for the Shoryuken again.
As noted in the description, I didn't have much to say about the ending other than this part. These stats have always kind of perplexed me. What exactly does "rp" stand for, anyways?

To note one more minor thing: X's charged shots also use different palettes when you perform this glitch (the semi-charged shots become yellow, and the full charged shots become a slightly glitched looking pink). This reverts once you get to the second phase or use the Shoryuken again.

The Shoryuken is pretty much the biggest game breaker available (in more ways than one). With that being said however, I absolutely suck at doing the input for it correctly. Maybe it's because I'm rusty at the game (or I just haven't played Mugen in a long time), but this input is just incredibly finicky for me at times.

There was a glitch up ahead that I wanted to show at first, though messed up (hence the transition effect). You can actually stand inside the room where Sigma and Zero show up without triggering them to appear, just so long as you don't walk too far to the right. If you perform a Shoryuken in the right spot, you'll actually trigger the cutscene, but when X lands, he won't readjust himself to go back to the left. If you get him to land in the center of the room, you'll immediately fall in the hole that Zero creates. Why is this important? Well...
